description: Coaching rubric for Technical Support Engineers focusing on issue resolution, customer experience, and knowledge transfer during post-sales support interactions

dimensions.name: Issue Diagnosis & Understanding
criteria: Asks clarifying questions to fully understand the reported issue
Gathers relevant context: environment, configuration, recent changes
Reproduces or confirms the issue before jumping to solutions
Identifies root cause vs symptoms
Documents the issue clearly for tracking and knowledge base

scoring.90-100: Excellent: Methodical diagnosis with targeted questions. Gathers complete context including environment details and recent changes. Confirms issue reproduction before troubleshooting. Accurately identifies root cause. Clear documentation.
scoring.70-89: Good: Asks relevant clarifying questions. Gathers most important context. Attempts to reproduce issue. Usually identifies root cause. Adequate documentation.
scoring.50-69: Needs Improvement: Incomplete questioning, misses key context. Jumps to solutions without confirming issue. Sometimes treats symptoms instead of root cause. Minimal documentation.
scoring.0-49: Poor: No clarifying questions. Assumes understanding without verification. Doesn't attempt to reproduce. Misdiagnoses issues. No documentation.

dimensions.name: Resolution Effectiveness
criteria: Provides accurate, working solutions to customer issues
Explains the fix clearly so customer understands what was done
Offers workarounds when immediate fix isn't available
Sets appropriate expectations on resolution timeline
Follows up to confirm issue is fully resolved

scoring.90-100: Excellent: Solutions are accurate and complete. Clear explanations of what was done and why. Provides effective workarounds when needed. Sets realistic timelines. Proactively follows up to confirm resolution.
scoring.70-89: Good: Solutions usually work. Explains fixes adequately. Offers workarounds. Reasonable timeline expectations. Follows up when asked.
scoring.50-69: Needs Improvement: Solutions sometimes incomplete or incorrect. Vague explanations. Limited workaround options. Unrealistic timelines. Inconsistent follow-up.
scoring.0-49: Poor: Incorrect or ineffective solutions. No explanation of fixes. No workarounds offered. No timeline communication. Never follows up.

dimensions.name: Customer Experience & Communication
criteria: Shows empathy for customer frustration and business impact
Communicates clearly without excessive jargon
Keeps customer informed of progress during troubleshooting
Manages expectations appropriately when issues are complex
Leaves customer feeling confident and supported

scoring.90-100: Excellent: Genuine empathy for customer situation. Clear, jargon-free communication. Proactive progress updates. Excellent expectation management. Customer feels valued and confident in support.
scoring.70-89: Good: Shows appropriate empathy. Mostly clear communication. Provides updates when prompted. Sets reasonable expectations. Customer feels adequately supported.
scoring.50-69: Needs Improvement: Limited empathy shown. Uses too much jargon. Infrequent updates. Poor expectation management. Customer feels uncertain.
scoring.0-49: Poor: No empathy, dismissive of concerns. Confusing communication. No progress updates. Sets unrealistic expectations. Customer feels frustrated and unsupported.

dimensions.name: Knowledge Transfer & Enablement
criteria: Educates customer on how to prevent similar issues
Points to relevant documentation, best practices, or training
Explains the 'why' behind recommendations, not just the 'what'
Identifies gaps in customer's understanding of the product
Empowers customer to self-serve for common issues

scoring.90-100: Excellent: Proactively teaches prevention strategies. Shares relevant docs and resources. Explains reasoning behind recommendations. Identifies and addresses knowledge gaps. Customer is more self-sufficient after interaction.
scoring.70-89: Good: Provides some prevention guidance. Shares some documentation. Explains recommendations. Notices obvious knowledge gaps. Customer learns something.
scoring.50-69: Needs Improvement: Focuses only on immediate fix, no prevention. Rarely shares resources. No explanation of reasoning. Misses knowledge gaps. Customer doesn't learn.
scoring.0-49: Poor: No knowledge transfer. No documentation shared. No explanations. Ignores knowledge gaps. Customer as dependent as before.

dimensions.name: Escalation & Collaboration
criteria: Recognizes when to escalate vs continue troubleshooting
Provides complete context when escalating to engineering
Collaborates effectively with other team members
Knows product boundaries and when issues require engineering fixes
Balances customer urgency with appropriate escalation paths

scoring.90-100: Excellent: Perfect judgment on when to escalate. Escalations include complete context and reproduction steps. Seamless collaboration with team. Clear understanding of product boundaries. Balances urgency appropriately.
scoring.70-89: Good: Usually escalates appropriately. Provides adequate context. Works well with team. Understands most product boundaries. Generally balances urgency well.
scoring.50-69: Needs Improvement: Escalates too early or too late. Incomplete escalation context. Limited collaboration. Unclear on product boundaries. Struggles with urgency balance.
scoring.0-49: Poor: Wrong escalation decisions. No context provided. Doesn't collaborate. Doesn't understand product boundaries. Ignores urgency or over-reacts.
